You can already see that I've given this book a high rating, so I'm going to break my pattern and start with the criticisms. This is partially because the criticisms I have are pretty small and also because they start with the book's very title and identity. The title, 1493: Uncovering the New World Columbus Created is clearly intended to read as a sequel to his previous book 1491: New Revelations of the Americas Before Columbus (which I also loved). This is not actually true though. The two books have incredibly different focuses, structures, and purposes. 1491 was essentially a history book, using a great deal of archaeological evidence and secondary sources to detail the vast and complex history of the Americas before and during the arrival of Europeans. Naturally, I assumed this book would be a follow-up detailing the history of the Americas after that momentous event, focused on indigenous inhabitants. 1493, though, is not a history book. It is an extremely varied book that jumps around regularly from topic to topic and forward and back in time, regularly following a train of thought through several centuries all with multiple divergences. I'm not precisely sure what I would call the book, but ultimately what it seeks to accomplish is to focus on all the myriad ways the connection of these two worlds changed the entire globe, not just culturally, but physically, with the entire natural landscape of the world undergoing massive changes with the introduction of foreign flora, fauna, and disease from one continent to another. And where 1491 focused clearly on the native inhabitants (whom Mann refers to as Indians when speaking of in general terms for complicated reasons), this book is far more focused on the rest of the world, detailing how vastly Europe, China, and Africa were affected by this exchange. The book seeks to essentially analyze the creation and refinement of a globalized, connected society which did not truly exist until after the Americas were contacted.  My criticism here has nothing to do with the books quality. I think this book was just as interesting and enlightening as the previous one. The only issue is that it delivers something entirely different than what readers are led to expect. People who want a history of "Indians" after Europeans arrived don't get the book they're looking for, and people who actually want what this book delivers are unlikely to discover it unless someone happens to recommend it to them.  My only other criticism is that the book is very unfocused. This is somewhat understandable since the scope of the book is such that it is basically attempting to touch on the entirety of our current world's circumstances, which isn't really possible to do in a single book, and so it relies largely on digging deep into a few specific examples as a way of showcasing the many other possible areas of focus. Aside from that, Mann just isn't an especially organized or focused writer, with each chapter going on so many divergences that I can't really say that most of them actually feel like they have a specific identity of their own. This is especially glaring in the Africa chapter. I was initially very intrigued at the prospect of looking into the history of Africa as it develops from American influence, but aside from a few mentions of corn/maize becoming a staple crop there (just like basically everywhere else in the world) the chapter doesn't really deal with Africa the continent at all. It does focus quite a lot on Africans, going into great detail on the slave trade and the history of escaped slave societies in the Americas (which was personally my favorite section of the book). But so much of the detail focused on Central and South American Indians that I often had to remind myself that this chapter was nominally focused on Africans. Now that I've gotten my complaints out of the way, let me say in no uncertain terms: this is a great book. I tend to have a harder time with non-fiction books holding my interest but I never wanted to put this one down in favor of the novels I was also reading at the time. The scattershot approach, while disorganized, meant that I never knew where the book was going to go next and there was a never-ending parade of surprises. And this book is surprising. It's amazing just how much of the history in this book is either glossed over or completely ignored by typical education institutions and largely unknown in pop-culture. It's not an exaggeration to say that it changed my view of the world as a whole.  A big part of what makes this book work well is Mann playing to his strengths. Mann has a history as a scientific journalist, and it shows very clearly in the way that he approaches the topics of this book through a scientific focus. Where most historical writings I've read tend to focus on the human element of "what happened when and why," Mann focuses very strongly on the "how." Delving deep into topics like diseases vectors and how certain groups of people develop immunity, agricultural innovations, and unintended spread of flora and fauna, Mann paints a very broad picture of the entire planet undergoing vast reconstruction without any intelligent agent working towards that end. He gets a little overboard sometimes (I know more about mosquitoes now than I ever wanted to) but the depth of explanations given for these things makes it possible to understand the full consequences and implications of things like new crops spreading across the ocean and how they may have caused life expectancy and population growth to skyrocket, or how the devastation of disease created the unique circumstances that facilitated the complex race relations between Europeans, Africans, and Indians in the Americas.   There is a lot of detail in this book that I simply knew nothing about, and that I think anyone interested in history of any kind would find interesting. Mann sheds a pragmatic light on the African and Indian slave trade using historical records that don't line up remotely with the vague sketches typically used to describe it in modern times. I think this book would be of especial interest to those interested in the history of African and indigenous American peoples since it devotes quite a lot of its word count to the complex relationships between those peoples that I've literally never seen any mention of before outside of a few specific stories. As I mentioned above my personal favorite part of the book was the history of "maroon" societies: independent polities formed by escaped African slaves living in concert with people from vastly different African societies, local Indians, and small scatterings of Europeans. I've always wondered why there weren't more successful slave rebellions or escapes in the Americas, and this section showed that my assumption was wrong: there were tons of such successful societies, many of them which waged war on colonial forces for decades or even centuries and many of which were eventually granted legal legitimacy. I recommend this book to anyone interested in the process of globalization, since that is ultimately what it is about, as well as those who are interested in the gaps in history that public education tends to ignore. Just know that this is very much not a book about America or Americans. The title "The New World Columbus Created" refers not to the formation of Europeanized America but to the creation of the global world as we know it, a world were the actions performed on one continent create ripples that have enormous consequences on every other one.  Trying to sum up this book is extremely difficult, so if anyone out there is considering reading it and has any questions on its content feel free to comment and ask me and I'll do my best to answer any questions you have.

Charles C. Mann's 1493 examines the impact of European colonization of the New World in a variety of fashions. Mann makes the argument that the Columbian Exchange was one of the Earth's most important events, with impacts both immediate and long-term, obvious and subtle. Not only white conquest and settlement (and the destruction of Native cultures) but the establishment of slavery, which in turn stimulated modern capitalism and devastated the African continent; not only disease and technology but the exchange of animals and crops with a truly worldwide impact, shifting entire ecosystems and uprooting human habits at once. Thus people, not only in Europe but Asia, Africa and the Middle East, found themselves reaping the benefits and drawbacks of a truly global economy: growing addicted to tobacco, sugar and coffee, refocusing cuisine and culture around maize and potatoes, valuing stimulated trade and capital as marks of "progress." It's all written in a surprisingly accessible fashion, with Mann juggling his various disciplines and approaches with enviable ease.

COLUMBIAN EXCHANGE, CHARLES C MANN, SLAVERYNothing Stands AloneIn Fleshed Out Tweets, Thoughtful- Items I'd Like you to Read on September 26, 2011 at 10:48 am Rate This Anyone who has ever received one of my tweets or is in my FB circle this week is aware that I am obsessing about “1493“ by Charles Mann.His prior book, that I read, “1491“ describes the Western Hemisphere just prior to interaction with Europeans. The gist of 1491 is that European technology and numbers were insufficient to conquer the native peoples of the Americas at the end of the 15th century. The number of indigenous peoples and the sophistication of their cultures far exceeds what was taught in school when I was a kid. The myth of virgin wilderness in the Americas is just that a myth. A remarkable global history from 1493 to the present, describes the trade and exchange of people, plants, commodities, and microorganisms between Europe, the Americas, Asia and Africa. It is nowhere nearly as original as Charles Mann's previous 1491, with presented a revolutionary portrait of pre-Columbian America, nor Guns, Germs and Steel, which covers some of the same terrain. But it is still a thoughtful, balanced, creative, and large-scale history of what the author, following earlier works, calls the "Columbian exchange." The book is journalistic in nature and draws on a wide variety of research including conventional history, genetics, environmental studies, farm studies, and economic history.Mann's thesis is that since 1493, a massive Transatlantic and Transpacific trade has helped create a new era in global environmental history, the Homogenocene -- which is a homogenizing of the people, plants and people around the world. Some of the exchanges he describes are well known and well documented, like the slave trade. Others I had never heard of, like the large role that the guano mining and trade played in 19th century agriculture. All of them are described in a vivid and humanizing way, for example describing the horrors of guano mining by essentially enslaved Chinese laborers, the boomtowns that it created in Peru, the cartels that controlled it, and the impact it had on European agriculture. In between these levels of familiarity, are detailed descriptions of the trade in tobacco, silver, the potato, rubber, rice, sugarcane, malaria and yellow fever.In the course of this, the book covers the agricultural revolution, the industrial revolution, the founding of the America's and the rise of Europe. It is also interesting in that it spends as much time on China and Asia, not just as a source of materials for the West but also in describing how the trade in items like silver and the potato transformed Asian economies, societies, and even their physical topographies. The Philippines get a particularly interesting treatment in the book, as the crossroads of the Asia, the New World, and Europe.I appreciate Mann's balance in writing the book. He is unstinting in his descriptions of the human and ecological horrors brought by the exchange. But he is also clear and forthright about their massive benefits that these exchanges have brought.

I thoroughly enjoyed Mann's other book on this general topic, 1491: New Revelations of the Americas Before Columbus, so I was quite keen to read this one. 1491 charted the history of America before Columbus' arrival and the dramatic changes that occured as a result. 1493 is in effect an expansion on a theory expounded in 1491, what is known as the Columbian Exchange. Whilst 1491 dwelt almost solely on the impact of Columbus' discovery of the America on the original inhabitants, 1493takes a global look at the impact of the Columbian Exchange, a worldwide translocation of people, plants, animals, pests and diseases as a result of the sudden contact between two previous disparate hemispheres.Crops previously indigeonous to the Americas becames staples across the world - potatoes. maize and tomatoes in Europe, peanut and manioc in Africa, rubber to Southeast Asia. And that's not mentioning the introduction of malaria and yellow fever to the Americas, or animals such as the horse and cow, even the honey bee! The impact in some places is staggering. Even something as small as an earthworm can destroy millennia-old systems of agriculture in less than a decade.It's quite sobering, in fact, just how much of an impact the introduction of one species to a new area can have on the native plants and animals. Dutch Elm Disease, for example, is a direct result of the Columbian Exchange. The potato blight is another. Grey squirrels in the British Isles driving out the native red population. Kudzu vine in America is another.This is a fascinating read, as I've come to expect from Mann, to see just how much the world has shrunk and homogenised over time. Plants that seem such a fixture of particular countries, like tomatoes in Italy or potatoes in Ireland, are in fact 'exotic' imports. The potato in particular had an immense effect on the population in Europe, and yet one hardly reads about it in the history books. I would personally make this book required reading for schools and colleges. It's an immensely important study, and reading the impact of what Mann calls the Homogenocene Era from a global perspective makes you realise just how small our world is now and how inter-connected. And how, one way or the other, we will all rise and fall together.

After I finished this book, for some reason I had a strange urge for a Big Mac... Considering I never ever eat fast-food, after reading this book I got a new sense of the world around me, looking differently at all these inventions of industry and society leading to world homogeneity...The 'Homogenocene' - an era of world history triggered by Christopher Columbus' arrival into the new world - a biological era referring to the mixing of unlike substances to create a new blend...From the silver found in the mountains of Bolivia which became Chinese currency, to tomatoes originated in South America that found its way as a staple into the Mediterranean diet...And from Europe's sweet tooth that drove an insatiable demand for sugar creating the sugar plantations run by African slaves, to the industrial revolutions need for rubber which gave way to espionage to find the best strains of the tree that would overcome disease leading to wealth....This book has it all... It's like so many books in one...From the origins of slavery in the Madeira and São Tomé islands, and how it thrived below the Mason-Dixon Line in the south of the US, to how it was affected and isolated by the spread of malaria and yellow-fever, eventually freeing the slaves allowing them to create new communities in the new world...It all points to The Colombian Exchange... A huge global shock to the way the planet has existed with its natural course of evolution...American history often describes Europeans entering a nearly empty wilderness.... This is a rambling, fascinating analysis of the origins of globalization and what Mann calls the "homogenocene," the homogenization of ecologies around the world since Columbus "discovered" the New World, and malaria was exchanged for potatoes, to oversimplify just a tad. Mann offers a balanced account of the benefit of this globalization that has been going on for centuries, and which if we have ever eaten tomatoes or corn, for example, we have benefited from. But he's far from blind to its often appalling costs. For example, the potted history of Sao Tome and Principe that he gives in the course of a few pages is one of the most depressing accounts of centuries of human greed, exploitation and misery I've read (the plantation system there served as a kind of model for slavery in the Americas).There are plenty of eye-opening surprises here. I was entirely ignorant of the fact that the first cowboys in the Americas were African slaves (probably on Cortes's vast estate South of Mexico City), and that indeed the cowboy tradition of freedom and reliance on nobody originated (oversimplifying again a bit obviously) not in the Western US, but on the plains of West Africa, with its millennia-old traditions of horsemanship and cattle tending. And there are also plenty of rather inspiring stories here of resistance of escaped African slaves and American Indians and other outsiders who established communities that managed in some cases to stay more or less under the radar into the present century. Another of the nuggets among tons of engrossing accounts that struck me was the fact that the Muslim solution in the Middle East to the fact that sugar production from sugar cane required intensive, readily available labor was to pay workers very well, so that they would be encouraged to stay. The Christian Europeans, who discovered sugar through the first Crusade, came up with their own, appalling solution to this labor problem.

An interesting look into the origins of the modern world and what the author calls Homogenocene Age. A homogenization of the world through the exchange of a small handful of plants and animals. Mann gets into the weeds of the Columbian exchange. One of the main drivers of this homogenization. And throughout much of the book, he shows the two sides of this coin. For example, bringing potatoes to Europe from the Andes gave nutrient rich food to millions of people. Probably preventing the Malthusian Trap of famine and death from increasing population growth. The fertilizer from bird shit in the Atlantic and Pacific further assisted agriculture, allowing exponential productivity out of the same land. But....... Mann asserts that the mold in that same bird shit, carted into Europe by the boatload, was the culprit for the eventual famine and death across Europe that followed. We know this as the Irish Potato Famine. What globalization gives, it also can take away. I also found the parts on China fascinating, for while the Europeans were pillaging and looting the Americas, China was content with being the foremost power in the world. It's not that they weren't interested in colonoization like the Europeans, it's that they didn't care. They didn't believe the rest of the world had anything to offer them, and for the most part, that assumption was true. Their interactions with the Spanish and their silver were some of my personal highlights of the book. I didn't find the whole book as riveting as 1491, but I think that's more a matter of taste than a reflection on the book. If anyone know a good book on the history of China, I am all ears.

This is a massive but not overly academic book (not jargon heavy at all!) that covers the birth of the modern world - the globalization that happened after the "discovery" of the New World - culturally, economically, and environmentally.Mann's research is amazing. And I've had enough rather specialized education in some of the areas he describes (like colonial Jamestown and 16-17th c. Mexico) to appreciate the depth of Mann's work.But the writing style - which makes complex ideas (even stuff I'm not at all interested in, like 16th c. Chinese economy and politics) accessible - is what really blew me away.In short, this was a perfect storm of ideas, research, and execution. This is the kind of thing that Michael Pollan did for food in "Omnivore's Dilemma", but for history, especially environmental history. If you have any interest at all in those topics, I can't recommend this highly enough. I learned an amazing amount about tobacco, rubber, guano, potatoes, mosquitoes, malaria, yellow fever, slavery, race and class in Latin America, Chinese pirates, silver, and Spanish and Portuguese conquistadors. Which all seems rather scattered, but Mann shows just how it's all connected and *very* relevant to our world today.I think this book will probably win some awards this year. If it doesn't, it definitely should.

This was an excellent study of how Columbus' "discovery" of the Americas completely revolutionised life across the earth in numerous ways and how it continues to do so till this day. In terms of content this book was excellent in its varied yet thorough approach to the topics it discussed and it certainly covered a wide range of these. A particularly refreshing approach the writer used was to abandon the Euro-centric approach that is usually adopted when discussing the colonisation of the Americas and trade with Asia and to suggest that actually Sino-centric and Afro-centric views are far more appropriate.Similarly refreshing also was that the author in discussing globalisation stayed neutral towards this often controversial concept, in doing so he repeatedly pointed out that we need to view the process of globalisation as a two way street that offers both gains and losses rather than something which is all bad or all good.My only complaint as such was that unfortunately the author didn't spend much time discussing the evolution of homogenized cultures as a result of the Columbian Exchange except other to hint at it briefly in the chapter that discussed the Maroons in the Americas. Despite this however I would highly recommend this book to anyone who was remotely interested in any of the varied topics it discusses.

I liked "1493" really much, because I am addicted to books which offer a broad range of historical facts, creating an overarching history of a certain era. This book is one of these rare books which create a new view on an era that one thought to know.Nevertheless, the book had its strong parts - and there were weaker parts, too. I especially liked the 1st chapter and the last one, which were the ones dealing with the first centuries of amerindian-european-african-asian contact. These were so lively and full of amazing facts, woven into a history of interacting parties all over the world, that I was simply astounded. The parts I would have liked to be more specific were the ones about the spread of European diseases in the Americas (which he mentioned with some fascinating facts about the results of this spreading but not got into too deeply) and about the interaction of biological species (apart from the Malaria insects, the potatoe, tobacco and sweet potatoes) between the continents. The author offerd an insight into these fields, but in my opinion he stayed at the outer sides of this fasscinating topic.

Fascinating exploration of the process of globalization, not in the late 20th or early 21st century, but via the economic, biological, environmental, and human ethnic/racial shifts that were triggered by the symbolic visit of Columbus to the New World. It is a thick book, and you can read it incrementally while you are also reading something else and still get full enjoyment from it. I haven't read Mann's lauded earlier work, 1491, but the complex interconnections discussed here reinforced knowledge I already had, taught me several things about places and time periods I didn't know sufficiently, and helped me see the intricate ways so much is interconnected. We are talking the whole planet here, so disabuse yourself from notions this is a just a book about White Europeans settling the Americas, and prepare to learn about the Orient and the Occident, Africa and Amazonia, integrating natural sciences, social sciences, history, and an appreciation for cultural traditions, practices, and beliefs as they change over time in societies all around the world.Mann has helped me rethink how I plan to give more than a few lectures in the future. Well done, and thank you, sir.

The older I get the more I understand the inter-connectedness of history. Mann, using a huge variety of sources, pulls together the way Columbus's "discovery" of the New World set in motion the way our world is connected today, from ecology, through food (can you say pizza?), slavery, and disease, to economics and political processes.I really liked this book, especially since it didn't just focus on the Europe to South America angle, but brought in the thriving trade with China. Mann admits that he left out many countries in the interests of simplifying a complex concept, but the book was very satisfying anyway.I recommend this for people who are even slightly interested in history. The Intro and first chapter were a little slow going, stick with it. They are worth reading in light of later chapters. I especially appreciated Mann's humor--not obtrusive, but fun.

This book is only in part a continuation of 1491's description of the Americas before Columbus. Spanning the period from then to the present, it is in part a history of biological exchange, in part a history of trade and, in repeated excurses, in part a history of the globalization of slavery. As regards the latter, most notable is how Mann makes slaves, particularly black slaves, the agents of their own--and the Americas'--history.

Mann purports 1493 to be an update, using new scientific evidence and access, of Alfred W. Crosby's ECOLOGICAL IMPERIALISM. This book is not nearly as informative as Crosby's books, but contains lots of narrative and background on people, rather than the "exchange". The reader would be much better off reading ECOLOGICAL IMPERIALISM itself as well as Crosby's other book: THE COLUMBIAN EXCHANGE.

Fascinating and also felt all over the place - I'm not sure how much of that was due to the audiobook format, but I was able to appreciate most of the flow of information, even if it sometimes felt transient.

Much like 1491, this book features a vague thesis (exchange between the Americas and the rest of the world in the past 500 years has shaped the present) over which Mann drapes digression upon digression, some of them fascinating, others decidedly less so, all thoroughly cited, but few of those citations referring to primary sources. Here's what I found interesting:Chinese demand for silver drove a great deal of European expansionWhen I think about the motives for European colonialism, I think of greed, flight from religious persecution, and geopolitical maneuvering. A Chinese capital sink was not on my radar, but Mann did a good job convincing me it played a role. I would have liked to see more exploration of what might have happened without a huge consumer for American silver. Inflation? Also, Chinese currency history and the endless successions of retribution in Potosi? Not that interesting. Summarize, cite, and move on, please.Jamestown was a corporate enterprise, not a government one.This was a minor point in the book, but I hadn't realized one of America's founding colonies wasn't exactly a bunch of people trying to reinvent themselves or the English crown making a land grab, but rather a corporation trying to turn a buck. Corporate greed is more deeply rooted in our history than I thought!Success of old-world tropical diseases predicated social institutions, particularly slaveryThis was one of his larger points. Aside from the irony that Europeans generally failed to survive in tropical regions of the Americas because of diseases they brought with them from the tropics in other parts of the world, Mann focused primarily on the way these diseases shaped demographics and cultural institutions, drawing mostly from the work of Daron Acemoglu, Simon Johnson, and James Robinson at MIT. Obviously it's hard/impossible to prove disease played a greater role than, say, suitability of an area for crops that can be grown en masse and require a lot of manual labor, but I think Mann successfully summarized the importance of disease. Acemoglu et al's work goes on to explore how differences in social / governmental institutions that were related to disease have influenced current economic success, basically pointing out that colonies where Europeans settled in large numbers are more economically successful today than colonies where they maintained small numbers but employed many slaves (they do a lot to separate the influence of disease on institution forming and the influence of institutions on economic success from other factors that I don't entirely understand, but I believe that's the gist). I wonder how this kind of analysis holds up when applied to US states, comparing slave and non-slave states.American tubers and tobacco facilitated population booms and population expansion into agriculturally marginal areas in China and Europe, facilitating huge social and landscape changesMany people seem surprised to learn that Italians hadn't heard of tomatoes before Columbus, or that the Irish weren't eating potatoes since the dawn of time, or that southeast asians weren't turbo charging their cuisine with hot chilies before Europeans showed up with their wimpy palates. If you're one of those people, be surprised no longer: all these veggies come from the Americas, along with tobacco, sweet potatoes, and corn/maize. If you're a food/history nerd, though, this probably isn't news. What I found interesting was the history of how productive, nutritional crops that could be grown in marginal soil abetted landscape changes in China (migration to hillier terrain, deforestation, increased erosion, catastrophic flooding), and how potatoes assuaged famine and may have effected political stability in European nations as those countries were industrializing and expanding their reach.There were many synthetic communities of escaped African slaves that survived well into the presentI was totally unaware of these "maroon" cities, so this was definitely interesting. Much as the bulk of 1491 was an effort to illuminate agency among American Indian peoples, these chapters did the same for Africans in the Americas. However, I wanted to see more about how these independent hybrid cultures influenced the present. Candomblé was mentioned, along with some of Brazil's other Christianish religions, but it would have been cool to learn about what components of these practices originated in maroon communities and not among slaves.  Overall, interesting stuff. I would have liked to see some exploration of one of Mann's least supported assertions in 1491, namely that American democratic principles were influenced by Indian example, but maybe he's saving that for another book.

This book is a fascinating look at the global, long-term impact of the arrival of Europeans in the western hemisphere. Mann's book "1491" was an examination of life in the western hemisphere before the arrival of Columbus in 1492, and while "1493" is not a "sequel" in the traditional sense of this word, it does pick up the story of arrival of the Europeans with Columbus's expedition, which is where the previous book ended. Mann's second book is actually a far more expansive look at the repercussions of the events of the late 15th century. The author's thesis is pretty simple: the notion of "globalization" did not begin in the 19th or 20th century, but actually in 1492, with the arrival of the Spanish in the western hemisphere. He does not focus so much on the notions of economic forces, but more on biology. In Mann's view, Columbus's arrival began the process of recreating Pangaea, the single continent that existed over 300 million years ago. His approach is both "macro" and "micro;" he describes the enormous changes brought about by the arrival of Europeans in the west whose impacts are still being felt, but the book also examines very precise topics like tobacco, silver, rubber, yellow fever and malaria, and grass. The last part of the book looks at the racial mixing that took place in the western hemisphere after 1492, with some surprising details, such as the fact that the Mexican people are an amalgamation of Indian, African, European AND Asian (Filipinos from the Spanish colony of the Philippines migrated to Mexico City), and autonomous mixed race (Indo-African) entities emerged all over the western hemisphere, including the Everglades of Florida and Virginia's Great Dismal Swamp. We live in an era when we reap the benefits of globalization while feeling the effects of a large groundswell of sentiment firmly aligned against these changes. But Mann's book makes a very convincing case that globalization has been taking place for half of a millennium and the resistance to it has existed for nearly as long. The book thus serves as an effective antidote for the historical parochialism with which we often find ourselves consumed.

I didn't read 1491, and was so impressed by this later book by Mann that I am definitely going to read it. 1493 is a fascinating treatment of how globalization was started at scale; the info on the Chinese silver trade and so forth was completely new to me, and in particular, the degree to which infectious disease, particularly malaria, played a significant role in the slave trade in the U.S. was also new to me. We read this book as a selection in an Environmental Book Discussion Group my husband and I attend monthly. I was particularly struck by the economic downstream consequences that resulted from Columbus's voyage and the aftermath.

In 1491, Charles Mann countered the western perception that Europeans discovered in the new world a pristine and largely vacant wilderness by illuminating what history now reveals: a landscape home to millions of people with sophisticated technologies, advanced agricultural practices, highly developed cultures, rich architecture and scientific knowledge. Through an avalanche of research and analysis he effectively concludes the pre-Columbian Americas afforded its peoples an overall quality of life that exceeded that of Europe. Full of new revelations, this book significantly altered the way I think about the societies that flourished here. The follow-up, 1493, continues this tradition by presenting the global aftermath of Columbus' accidental discovery of the new world, which Mann argues is one of the most significant events in human history. To make his point, Mann profiles several profound and significant "agents of the Columbian exchange," - the people, places, raw materials, plants, animals and diseases that shaped a world suddenly reconnected for the first time since tectonic plates ripped apart the continents 200 million years ago. Globalization is a term associated with the 1980s and 90s, but its first act had a much more profound and spectacular impact. Mann describes divergent worlds that found themselves standing beside one another and intermixing with unknown and enormous consequences. This was an era when the world changed overnight, over and over again, which makes for a fascinating read.Like 1491, this book pieces together blurry and incoherent scraps of history into a vivid, richly illustrated narrative that provide a small and mesmerizing glimpse into the souls swept up by the Columbian Exchange. In doing so, it challenges popular perceptions of the new world - shifting credit from kings and queens to malaria, potatoes, and fruit.Mann looks at history and the world through a giant lens, but is able to focus on and weave together fascinating examples that illustrate the profound and otherwise forgotten moments that dramatically altered human life.--------------------------A few crazy byproducts of the Columbian Exchange that struck me while reading (best discovered in the book and not this list but here for my own recollection):- New studies suggest the Little Ice Age that plagued Europe resulted from the lack of controlled burns by Indians in North America upon European arrival. By allowing thousands of acres of forests to regenerate, the release of carbon was reduced resulting in a man-made global cooling effect that dropped temperatures worldwide.- The first true global economy took hold in current-day Mexico City, which became the center of commerce for precious medals, silk, tobacco, slaves and all sorts of plants and foods.- Tobacco: the first worldwide pop sensation. Nobody needed it, but everyone had to have it.- Malaria and yellow fever drove the African slave trade because Africans fared much better against the viruses than Europeans and Indians (yellow fever, it should be noted, is a really really bad way to go).- Europeans imported the "English fly," or European honeybee to North America for honey, well before anyone realized the role bees play in pollination.- Potatoes, the staple of Ireland that lifted much of Europe from famine (and once disease hit, back into it), actually originate from the Andes.- The reintroduction of the earthworm to the upper regions of the United States for the first time since the glaciers wiped them out.- The insane harvesting of rubber and its role in the industrial revolution.- The South American city of Potosi, then the wealthiest place on earth, where thousands of enslaved Indians with candles strapped to their foreheads worked endlessly inside poorly ventilated ore mines.- The long-running success of "maroons," in creating large populations, possibly "discovering" the Pacific, and negotiating with emerging governments.

I was deeply and thoroughly impressed with Mann's monumental tome. It was every bit, if not more, sweeping in its treatment of the New World as his previous book 1491 documenting what we know about pre-Columbian America. Coupled with Ian Morris's book on "Why the West Rules - For Now" https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/9... this promotes a far more egalitarian look at history, offsetting much of the Euro-centric conventional wisdom that passes for history in today’s schools. I may not agree that “those who win get to write the history books,” but for far too long, the winners have overwhelmingly dominated the conversation. 1493 is a nice corrective. A number of other reviewers express disappointment in the book for a variety of reasons and if I could summarize them, it would be due to this book failing to live up to their expectations. From my perspective, I question whether those expectations are warranted or not. Mann covers a broad sweep beginning with biology and moving into sociology and ultimately politics. What he has done is to fuse that which in my previous experience has been treated wholly separately. As a biology major, I remember time and again studying about invasive or exotic species and their impact on agriculture. Rarely did I hear about the benefits, either socially or ecologically, of the imports. As one example, I never knew that earthworms were introduced to North America, but I have known since my earliest childhood of how important they were to gardening. This was a startling revelation to me. Not only did I have no idea that something so profound is a result of the Columbian Exchange, but how it could be so universally unknown among my peers. This historical tidbit helps explain how thousands of years of indigenous forest management using fire was effectively replaced by forest management using earthworms and what an impact that had on ecology. And that is just one tiny little organism. I have known that Great Lakes fisheries survive today based on management of introduced species like the Coho and Chinook salmon while unintended immigrants like the Asian carp and zebra mussel are greeted with fear, despair, and antipathy. While I recognize the problems associated with introduced organisms, I have a lot of confidence in nature’s ability to sort things out. Over time. Mostly. Mann helps illustrate the pros and cons of an Exchange that continues to this day and shows no sign of letting up.Where Mann excels is tying these ecologic stories to a broader ecosystem that embraces human society. He moves smoothly from agriculture and nature to society and it’s give-and-take within the ecology it both finds and disrupts. From there he moves through politics and history, not quite, but nearly re-writing the Euro-centric view of the New World. If nothing else, he deserves accolades for looking at the data and writing about the massive shifts in human demography that took place as a result of the Columbian Exchange. I highly recommend this book as a must-read for anyone who wants to approach history from an incredibly broad perspective that encompasses everything from nature to politics. For someone who wants a “new perspective” on the history of the New World and its global impact, this is a great place to start. Mann points out that the Columbian Exchange is, above all, a genuine EXCHANGE. The roads all run both ways in this book and that is a refreshing interpretation in today’s academic climate.

This was a fascinating work of synthesis, wherein Mann draws on a variety of current scholarly sources to chronicle the genesis of globalization after 1492 and the forces unleashed by it, both constructive and destructive. He examines the impact of the spread of different microbes, animals, insects, foodstuffs, and ultimately, people, into and out of the Western Hemisphere, and how it transformed ecologies and economies. Some examples: he shows how the spread of maize and sweet potatoes from the Americas into China resulted in the ecological destruction of much of China, primarily due to deforestation, erosion, and exhaustion of land fertility from the 1500s even unto the present day; the spread of Africans into the Americas and the plight of slaves and creation of communities of escaped slaves ("Maroons"), and the legacy of these communities forming a permanent underclass of the dispossessed in Brazil and elsewhere. He shows the spread of the potato and also the spread of the potato blight and the Colorado potato beetle. They say that history is written by the victors, but this is history from the other side. Even more admirable is how he brings the history forth into the present time, showing how the extractive and exploitative actions of governments and corporations, continue to exploit the dispossessed, to ruinous effect. Mankind still seems prone to the same kind of selfish barbarities that have inflicted untold suffering over the centuries. No armchair scholar is Mann - he writes of his trips to China, Brazil, Mexico, and the Philippines and his interviews of native scholars, officials, and peasants, together with his visits to the actual sites. One of my favorite lines describes the inequality of a Laotian village elder (who is 30 years old), in negotiating a contract with a large Chinese company for rubber tree production - that the contract showed that 'one side had lawyers to maximize its contractual rights, and the other side didn't know what a lawyer was.' Mann's writing style is engaging and erudite. He maintains a certain sense of humor throughout the book. His footnotes and list of sources is extensive, comprising perhaps the last 20% of the book. Over the years, my tastes have become somewhat jaded, so I am drawn to and prize originality. This is a very original work of a vast scope - the exploration of the Columbian Exchange and its legacy. It is much greater than the sum of its parts. I give it 5 stars for this.

I'm familiar with the phrase "the Columbian Exchange", but never spent much time working out all its nuances. Charles C. Mann takes up the topic in 1493. In a nutshell, the Exchange is the process through which the combination of old world and new world elements has interacted to form the global culture of today. Mann, not a historian himself, synthesizes a generation's worth of research and literature into a lively, readable exposition on the political, cultural, and biological forces that were unleashed. Most such chronicles focus upon technology as the driving force in economic and social development. The Europeans, for instance, had superior weaponry and therefore easily conquered the New World's indigenous peoples. But Mann argues that biological forces were much more influential in determining outcomes.  Opening with the first prolonged contact between cultures along the Atlantic coast, Mann describes how micro-organisms from the Europe, Asia, and Africa hitched free passage to the Americas, causing a myriad of problems that could not have been foreseen and were poorly understood at that time. The colonies nearly failed until a profitable commodity crop, tobacco, was established. It was a micro-organism that enabled an American victory in the war for independence, and other micro-organisms fostered the enslavement of Africans in many countries. Mann then moves on to the Pacific, where he looks at silver, corn, and piracy, and their effects on both sides of that vast ocean. His discussion of the food that enabled China's population growth is particularly fascinating. Finally, he moves on to Europe and Africa, and provides an overview of the economy underlying the slave trade from the African point of view. Many men who were sold into slavery were prisoners of war, soldiers with military training, who put that experience to good use fomenting successful rebellions in Central America. It's daunting to review a book of this size and scope, so rich in facts and detail. But it's not dry detail. There were streets in South America, for example, that really were paved, not in gold, but silver. Europeans "drank" tobacco, and had elaborate rules and rituals surrounding the practice. And that the influence of the lowly sweet potato has been enormous. 1493 is not a polemic or a sales pitch. It is a thoughtful, fair, and balanced tour de force with the power to change how we view the world.

This may be the most interesting non-fiction book I have ever read. This is the sequel to 1491 which was a history of the Western Hemisphere before Columbus. 1493 is a detailed history of what happened right afterward and how the world was changed by the "Columbian Exchange" or the restoration of Pangaea. It is amazing how different the world is today because of the exchange of people, animals, plants and diseases. Before the Columbian Exchange there was no tomato, potato, pepper, or rubber anywhere in the Eastern Hemisphere. The industrial revolution would not have been possible without rubber. By 1800 most of the Europe and Asia were living off of the potato and it allowed the world population to double just based on the new food that could be grown. Potatoes are less vulnerable to blight or bad weather which reduces the chance of famine. The book goes through the detailed stories of the first conquistadors: Columbus, Balboa, De Soto, Cortez, Pizarro. It's fascinating to know how human they were and the mistakes they made but also the amazing will power they had. There are so many fascinating stories that you would never read about in a history book about all of the strange things. There are lots of fascinating stories about a black guy who was a freed man from Spain who established the very first church in Mexico in around 1520 and the Western Hemisphere, and also planted the first grains which was the original ancestor of all of the wheat grown in most of north and south America. From 3 grains gave birth all of that wheat which is why it is so genetically homogeneous and susceptible to blight and pests. The same is true for the potatoes taken to Europe and Asia, they all came from the same few potatoes which means that when a bacteria likes that potato then it likes all of them. Also, there was a different black guy named Esteban who was part of an expedition of 500 who came to the Caribbean in the early 1500s. Due to shipwreck, disease, starvation, and skirmishes with injuns, pretty soon there were 4 left and these guys just wandered naked through the southeast US from Florida to Texas. Esteban became some kind of faith healer and the indians started to revere him as some kind of saint or spiritual man. Lots of great stories like that.

In 1972, historian Alfred W. Crosby Jr. published a book called “The Columbian Exchange.” If I understand correctly, it attempted to map the impact of the world-wide trade routes that arose after Columbus sailed the ocean blue. Mann reports he bugged Crosby to update the book so many times that Crosby finally snapped at him “you do it.” 1493 is that update. It tells the tale of the world’s transformation into one integrated financial, cultural, and biological system. The general shape of the story is well known. Mann fleshes out a lot of details. Brutally summarized, it comes down to “it was worse than I knew and faster.” Among other things, I learned:•	Scotland finally joined the United Kingdom after England agreed to pay Scottish debts related to a failed colony in Panama.•	Many British investors in Jamestown believed it was only a few days march from the Pacific and were quite peeved the colonists hadn’t gotten there so they could get on with the serious business of trading with China.•	Sir Francis Drake led a raid on a Spanish mule train carrying silver that would have been terribly successful except for one drunk French guy. •	But for malaria, the North likely would have won the Civil War so fast that there would not have been the political will for the Emancipation Proclamation or the 14th Amendment.•	17th Century Chinese tax policy led directly to massive deforestation and loss of top soil despite royal decrees that would have stopped the land management systems that wrecked so much havoc.•	An African princess and general, sold to Portuguese slavers, escaped and founded a military settlement in Brazil that controlled a large area of the coastal mountains for decades. •	Cortes fathered children on several of Moctezuma’s daughters. He also successfully petitioned the pope to legitimate a child he fathered on his interpreter. •	Pizarro fathered several children on different Inca princesses. One married his brother. The book is sprawling and occasionally self-indulgent but utterly engrossing. Well worth the time.

This is a good, thick book that will take a while to read. Every once in a while, you will probably want to do what I did and put it down and think about what you've just read and perhaps do some fact checking. I was particularly interested because Mann talks quite a bit about the importance of Fujian province in China and the incredible trade that sprung up there. He uses Fuzhou and neighboring ports to illustrate the first global trade cities - by 1340, Zaytun in Fujian province had seven mosques, three churches and a cathedral as well as the usual Buddhist institutions. Having been to Fujian province this year, I enjoyed learning more about its history. As Mann discusses the history of world trade, he also talks about the unintended consequences of that trade - the freeloaders that came on ships to change the "new" world forever - these were insects, illnesses and plant life. While we Westerners may be used to thinking of the English as destroying indigenous peoples with diseases and being new crops, we may not often think of them as changing the lives of those people forever by their farming methods. Indians traditionally burned land to clear it. This encouraged the growth of trees and shrubs whose seeds only opened when fired such as loblolly, long leaf and slash pines. As English methods of planting by chopping down trees and plowing land increased, trees such as oak and hickory filled in the forests and this may have impacted the amount of carbon dioxide in the air - today's climate change in reverse. Just one example of the information in this book to think about and fact check. Fascinating!

The premise of this book is interesting: globalization, contrary to being a recent phenomenon, has been occurring since the time of Christopher Columbus. The method of argument is unique, using biological and ecological explanations, rather than the standard political ones. And the sheer number of counter-intuitive facts is simply astounding. Did you know that the potato, which now spans much of Europe, originated from the Andes, and that Peruvian guano was exported to Europe to be used as its fertilizer? Or that African slaves, who outnumbered Europeans in the Americas until the late 1800s, possibly proliferated because they were more resistant to strains of malaria that decimated the white and "Indian" populations? Or that the earthworm was introduced to the US during the tobacco trade?The main problem with the book, however, is that it lacks focus. 1493 spans the mid-to-late 1400s to present time, Asia through Europe, has scattered observations about slavery, famine, and trade, and discusses so many different nations vying for wealth that it's hard to keep everything straight. Admittedly, history tends to be messy, but I was hoping for less meandering by Charles Mann. I have read that his earlier book, 1491, has this focus, and I would not hesitate to read that when I'm up for history-reading again.

A person of average-or-better intelligence probably knows, on some level, that our world fundamentally changed in and/or shortly after 1492, how often do we really sit and contemplate those changes? This book is 500 some-odd pages of that contemplation (and I mean that as a compliment). I dove into this book head-first after reading 1491: New Revelations of the Americas Before Columbus. I'll be honest: I liked 1491 better. However, I'll be honest again: It's probably because of my own interests and biases. In 1491, Mann focuses (mostly) on what the Americas, while the geographical scope in 1493 is much broader. I've been on an Indigenous history kick lately, so 1491 was an easier, more satisfying read. That said...I'm glad I took the time to work through this book. Even if, as mentioned previously, I understood on some level how much our world changed in 1492, I didn't have an appreciation for the multi-directionality of that change. If nothing else, by reading this book I've gained a deeper understanding (beyond the human migration element... exploration, slavery, immigration) of the degree to which the "discovery" of the Americas affected Europe/Asia/Africa.

Fascinating and sprawling history - maybe a little too sprawling as many of the topics could easily be separated into their own books. The book traces the changes brought about by the Columbian Exchange - the mixing of culture, people, plants (domesticated and otherwise), livestock, and micro-organisms as a result of re-discovery of America. Mann tracks changes in world population growth rates brought on by new crops, the devastating spread of previously unheard of diseases in both directions, environmental changes due to the introduction new domesticated plants and animals as well as new farming techniques, and the changes to culture and migration. It's both an improvement and expansion of the Columbian Exchange by Alfred Crosby (though not entirely a replacement - that books's still worth reading as well). Mann does a great job in spreading beyond the Western Europe/Americas dichotomy, giving equal weight to the effects of the exchange between the Americas and Asia and the Americas and Africa. For me, the most interesting section was the history of maroon societies - settlements founded by escaped African slaves, Asian workers, and Native Americans throughout North, Central, and South America - which continue a present day influence.

•	This was a pretty ambitious book that was well-researched and provided lots and lots of information•	I enjoyed how the world was seen as a whole and how something that seems as simple as a plant transported for a purpose or for no known reason could affect an area where it was not a native plant•	The author actually traveled to most of the places mentioned in the book so looks at the history, affect, and what it means to the people native to the area•	I learned about how the Chinese was brought to the Americas in the 1600s and the affect on South America – this was much earlier than I thought•	The author also does a good job of showing the role of Africans that were brought to the Americas either as free men or slaves and establishment of towns in South and Central Americas•	There is something here for everyone – but I paid more attention to the history and cultural parts than the scientific explanations – but it was all done in an engaging way.•	Learned about the different types of malaria brought to North America and why one thrived more in the South and the other in the North•	I enjoyed this book enough so will read - 1491: New Revelations of the Americas Before Columbus

This follow up to 1491: New Revelations of the Americas Before Columbus has more relevance and is arguably an important read to understand currently agricultural and even cultrual aspects of the "homogecene" era prompted by the Columbian Exchange. Resonating with Pollan's The Botany of Desire: A Plant's-Eye View of the World, Mann recounts the history of potatoes from Andean tuber to edible pesticide. Other amazing chapters of this microhistory is the Asian exchange with the galleon trade leading to a 16th Century Chinatown in Mexico City and Mexican silver en masse relocated to China.I particularly enjoyed and got a lot out of the theme that this late 15th Century activity started a wave of globalism that ramped up quickly and we still feel today. Two examples of that were ex-Confederate refugee rubber plantation founders in Sao Paulo, Brazile (http://www.patsabin.com/lowcountry/co...) and the failed Darien scheme of Scottish colonists in Panama.

The principal theme of the book is to chronicle the consequences of European exploration of Asia, Africa and the Americas. Using the arrival of Christopher Columbus in the Americas as symbolic of the beginning of what we now call globalization, the impacts on trade, on the environment, on culture and on politics are explored in some detail. Because the scope of the book is so vast, the author occasionally seems to have lost focus and to be meandering through a thicket of episodes in human history, but the journey is always a fascinating one, filled with surprises and thought-provoking hypotheses. Like Howard Zinn's A People's History of the United States, the book offers perspectives on history that are not commonly given. Whether one ends up agreeing with some of the claims—for example, that malaria ended up playing a key role in the fact that Americans of European descent preferred African slaves over the Indian slaves being sold by the Moskogean peoples, because West Africans were less likely to succumb to the disease—one will never be wanting for thought-provoking hypotheses. Readers willing to be gently jarred out of their customary ways of viewing history are likely to find the book delightful. Others may be slightly annoyed.

While I didn't enjoy this book as much as his last book (1491), I still think it was very thought provoking. This book is primarily focused on the Colombian Exchange. He first details out the usual North American ecological and human exchanges, then moves to South America. While talking about the Americas, he also talks a great deal about Asia and Africa at this time, because they were as important in the exchange as Europe and N. and S. America. I think he did a good job explaining such a complex topic, though the end of the book starts to feel rushed, like he had a lot more to say and not enough pages. This is probably only the last 20 pages or so, the rest is written at a much more measured (and detail packed) pace. It's a very dense read, nothing that can be skimmed, but he does provide a number of helpful maps, pictures, paintings, etc to illustrate what he's talking about, and makes a number of points that really make you pause and think.I would recommend this book to anyone who liked his last book (this is kind of a continuation), or anyone who is interested in ecology, geography, history, etc. It really has a little bit of something for everyone.

"A deeply engaging new history of how European settlements in the post-Columbus Americas shaped the world, from the bestselling author of 1491. Presenting the latest research by biologists, anthropologists, archaeologists, and historians, Mann shows how the post-Columbian network of ecological and economic exchange fostered the rise of Europe, devastated imperial China, convulsed Africa, and for two centuries made Mexico City -- where Asia, Europe, and the new frontier of the Americas dynamically interacted -- the center of the world. In this history, Mann uncovers the germ of today's fiercest political disputes, from immigration to trade policy to culture wars. In 1493, Mann has again given readers an eye-opening scientific interpretation of our past, unequaled in its authority and fascination."~~back coverThis is a very fascinating book -- not an easy read but certainly not so academic that the average reader can't understand and appreciate. This is a slow read -- a good deal of thought-provoking facts and conclusions; dense, and is probably best read in small doses.

Charles Mann's 1491, about the world just before Columbus's voyage west, was an eye-opener. I found it very well written and seemingly extremely well-researched. In 1493, about what happened after 1492, the same level of research is evident, but the book is much less successful.I'm not sure my disappointment is due to the research I've done since I first read 1491. That was wehn I was beginning work on my own book about exploration and its effects, Making Waves: The Continuing Portuguese Adventure (Véhicule Books.) Mann cites many of the sources I went on to read and which I cite, so the surprise factor in 1943 is much less than in 1491 for me. The book deals extensively with the Columbian Exchange, that is, the way that plants and animals from the New World were brought to the Old World and vice versa. This global exchange is leading toward a homogenizing of the entire world, leading to what Mann calls the era of the Homogonocene. The idea is interesting, but I must admit I had trouble even pronouncing the word in my head which meant I had trouble absorbing the concept.

Been busy, so slow at reading this--but it's terrific, a sweeping history of everything. Or a sweeping history of how world-wide trade changed with the European discovery of the New World, and how trade drove, and drives, ecological and cultural changes, good and bad, in all the world.The subtitle is misleading; the eponymous year of the title is merely a handy jumping off point for when what has been called The Columbian Exchange began. The erudition and enlightening detail of this book is wonderful. Who knew the North American continent lacked earthworms until European settlers arrived? Who knew Spanish silver from its New World mines mattered most to ... China? Who knew the monoculture of rubber was so destructive to SE Asia, or that honeybees were known as "English flies" to the indigenous tribes of the Atlantic coast?It's a little like chaos theory meets Guns, Germs, and Steel; but Mann's research is deep and his arguments logical and well thought through.

I read this last month and didn't have time to review it immediately, which will unfortunately make this review vaguer than it should be. I loved 1491, which I definitely count as a book that changed my perspective on the world. This sequel is more miscellaneous. Where 1491 had a clarion main idea--that pre-Columbian America was far more densely populated and richly sophisticated than we learned in school--the sequel charts repercussions of "the Columbian Exchange" more episodically. Some of the more worthwhile sections concern communities of escaped slaves in South America, yellow fever and malaria at different latitudes in the New World, and how the potato both fed Europe and doomed parts of it to famine due to a blight that was itself imported from the Americas. This book felt longer, more loosely held together, and less surprising. Not as good as the first one, but still worth a read.

'1493' is a must read for any history buff and should be required reading in high school or university. What really happened to the 'native' populations after Cristoforo Colombo aka Cristóbal Colón rediscovered the 'New World'? Are we all really that different from one another? How did slaves and mosquitoes sculpt the history of North and South America? Was the allure And extraction of precious metals that romantic? The fascinating Columbian Exchange globalized the planet long before today's globalization. In history class we learned that things were mostly hunky-dory in North and South America. Little did we know and less were we taught. Many surprises bring somber thoughts and realizations.

This book explores all the ways in which people, vegetables, animals and disease that were confined to the eastern or western hemisphere for centuries spread across the world in what Mann calls "the Columbian exchange". The world became more homogeneous as a result, where many things people think of as their native customs, fruits, and foods were actually imports from a few generations ago. The process of this grand exchange has a lot of interesting stories and side-stories, and side-stories to those side-stories. Mann loves to takes us down a lot of by-ways, sometimes even within a single paragraph. This could be a distraction if one wants to stick to a simple theme, but the point of this book is to take in all the little tendrils that have tied the world into a single whole.

While exceedingly broad and almost arbitrary in its topics, this was a useful survey of the big-picture trends and forces unleashed by intercontentental exchange in the post-Columbus world. Mann is at his best discussing the impact of silver, sugar, rubber, tobacco, coffee, potatoes, and corn on the economies and ecosystems of entire civilizations. The sheer force of these commodities radically transformed land and people from China to Brazil and everywhere in between.I found Mann less interesting when he shifted from economics and ecology and into social history. While I can't fault him from trying, his attempts add a couple hundred pages to a book that would have been about as good without it.

This was a wonderful book, well written and engaging, The topic considers the Columbian exchange, or how the world dealt with or was affected by the beginnings of a global economy. While some threads were previously known (yellow fever), other threads were astonishingly new (China's silver based monetary system). But all threads gave me new and thrilling understanding of an era that seemed so ho-hum in history class. Asians in the New World, pirates, working conditions, collaboration between African slaves and Native Americans, plantation slavery model, spread of food as a way to improve life for the malnourished, are all covered. As with anything, the Columbian Exchange cannot be profiled as good or evil, but instead is a very complex subject that deserves sustained consideration.

A highly interesting book, though not so much as its predecessor. Perhaps because it focuses more on the effects to Europe, Africa and China and the rest of Asia over those of the Americas, which is where my interest lies when it comes to this time. But when Mann does refocus on the Americas the book really takes off. The history of its people, and how they interacted with the Europeans and, especially, Africans, makes for some fascinating reading.The world created, to both the detriment and benefit to all the continents, is the one we’re still dealing with today, with all its devastation. And the pluses, too. Where would we all be without rubber? Or corn? Or the potato, which fed huge parts of Europe? But one does get the idea that the New World got the raw end of the deal.

Very readable, and just packed full of "wow" - a must-read. One of those books which changes your whole perspective on things. So many things I didn't realize: the extent to which the native population of the Western Hemisphere was decimated by disease post 1542, the number of slaves imported into SOUTH America, the extent to which CHINA was changed by its interaction with Europe (and European exlorers/traders/settlers of the New World), the influence of malaria on the history of the hemisphere, how importation/exportation of plant life changed things, how quickly everyone got hooked on tobacco...the list goes on and on.

1493Short review: read the awesome 1491!Slightly less short review: The book should have been called The Continuous Economic and Ecological Devastation of Everything Everywhere since 1493. Those concepts are important, of course, and are, at some points in this sprawling yet disjointed dissertation, really interesting. But wading through very, very long passages about the genetics of potatoes or the nature of elastomers to get to those all too brief gems is asking too much. Causal historians will be bored. Hard core historians will want much more detail – about specific things. Know-it-alls will be - well, maybe that group will love to cull trivia from the book.

1493: Uncovering the New World Columbus CreatedThis may be the best book ever written. Describes how world trade was transformed after Columbus's discovery of America. Tobacco was spread across the world. Silver mined in America by Spaniards became the currency. in China. Malaria from (mostly immune) African slaves wiped out Europeans and Native Americans. Europeans amazed by the properties of Amazonian rubber trees. Potatoes became a staple for much of the world and was devastated by the following blight, especially in Ireland. Rural China planted American crops and devastatingly mismanaged their farm lands resulting in a Malthusian catastrophe.

Thoroughly enjoyed this book and feel it should be required reading for history classes. Most of what I remember learning in school about the Columbian Exchange was along the lines of "he went to prove the world was round and in search of gold, jewels, and spices; Europeans brought small pox which killed the indigenous people." This book clears that fallacy and discusses the economics of trade, and how various goods (tobacco, potatoes, sweet potatoes, silver, slaves, etc) as well as disease (malaria, yellow fever) were exchanged.

Okay John Stewart- did you actually read this book?After recommendations from NPR shows and The Daily Show, I picked up this tome of history. The book starts off with a bang- chock full of great facts. Then, the author inputs personal anecdotes of his visits to some of these places, as well as a ridiculous flying metaphor. These devices were very distracting from the original narrative.Then, the book meanders pretty much through all known history. Too much information, too unfocused, and ultimately boring. Not recommended.

The biggest message i got out of this read was, Globelization is here, has always been here, so get over it. We need to figure out how to work with other economies and manage policies. There has to be a way to create more understanding, fairness and tolerance. Suppose that is a long shot especially given the ample history shared in this book.  Its a good read. Gives a good general backround for understanding the history of our global economy. Most of us wont want to dig any deeper. But for those who decide to after reading this book. Seems a great place to start.

A fascinating book full of facts and stories.It shows how the entire world has been affected by unknown consequences. The author did a good job of inter-mixing interesting stories with the dry facts. I am glad I read this as an audio book. There was so much information I don't think I would have been willing to wade through the paper version and that would has been as loss for me. The narrator was very good and easy to listen to. I learned many things from this book and would recommend it to anyone who wonders just how things in this world got to where there are now.

Wow. Coming off of “1491,” Mann does it again. “1493” is a perfect follow up, and it is just as well written, well told, and well structured. He weaves a story of trade and commerce over both the Atlantic and the Pacific, and how the continents—and countries—interacted with each other now that the Americas were in the picture. He brings up different points of view that made me think, and he shows new facts and details that should be—and should have been—told in classrooms.I definitely recommend this as a read.

Charles Mann writes the type of book that should be read in history classes everywhere. This one takes off where 1491 left off and is equally as fascinating. The amount of material covered is enormous but never overwhelming. Topics include everything from the potato famine to tobacco farming to both sides of slavery all over the world. Mann doesn't simply tell us when things happened. He tells us how and why. 1493 is well written, easy to follow and incredibly informative.

I liked 1491, but found 1493 pretty boring and overly speculative. It's like reading book reports on various unrelated topics that Mann researched. He tries to connect this all together with the "Columbian Exchange" but that's not new, and despite the tons of detail I didn't feel like I got a deeper or updated understanding there. The main point of that (Old World germs wiped out New World people) was just taken as a given.

Revised everything I had been taught about the history of the New World so completely that I have to worry "is this a pop myth-buster or real history?" Took the book on a plane trip (where I usually read thrillers) planning a quick dip but stayed engrossed the whole trip and praised the book to others. My brother in law gave this book and the companion, 1491, to my wife. I found 1493 more convincing because it had more documentation of post-Columbus commerce and a more worldwide span.
As heard on "Fresh Air".Maybe I should read 1491 first.***The January 2016 selection for the University of Chicago Alumni and Friends Baltimore Book Club.

1493 is an impressive undertaking; the narrative is sweeping and varied. The sections are reasonably well-contained and it is easy to skip over parts that you are less interested in, but each story is pretty interesting. I gave three stars because it was more than I wanted to chew, don't let it deter you from picking this up.

Easily one of the best and most enjoyable reads surrounding the post contact period. There is so much to say about Mann's interpretation, but my first thought is that I had never read anything remotely close to this, at least among fellow latinamericanists. For certain, I can think of NO textbook on Colonial Latin America that even comes close to this enjoyable of a read....just saying...
