1493 is a history of what Mann calls the "Columbian Exchange", a term used to describe the global-scale of trade ushered in by Christopher Columbus when he discovered the New World. This Columbian Exchange stirred up ecologies and economies all over the world, as new plants, animals, and microbes were introduced, edging out the existing competition.Some of these radical changes included:- The introduction of European microbes to the Americas, which killed 3/4 of the entire population of the Americas, and lead to the destruction of several large empires, including the Inca and the Aztec Triple Alliance.- Potatoes were brought from the Americas to Europe, and allowed for an explosion in population across Northern Europe. Famines were common and regular prior to the potatoes arrival. Potatoes are ~4x more productive than wheat as measured by dry weight (water removed) of food produced per acre of farmland. Potatoes have all essential nutrients save vitamins A and D, which you can get from animal milk. - At the start of Ireland's potato famine, 4 in 10 Irish ate no solid food except potatoes. The famine was a cross-country apocalypse, reulting in a 20-25% drop in the population. It killed >1 million people, and 2-3 million fled the country. "As late as the 1960's, its population was half as it had been in 1840" and today it has a smaller population than 150 years ago (perhaps the only country where this is true)- Maize and sweet potatoes were brought to China, and allowed for agriculture to spread uphill from the existing rice-based farming. This exacerbated flooding in China thanks to mass deforestation and erosion and killed a lot of people / destabilized governments - Slavery in the Americas began as mostly white-on-white indentered servants. Between 1/2 and 1/3 of all European migrants in the first 100 years of the American colonies were indentured servants. But African-natives showed a markedly better survival rate against Malaria (which came from - In fact, the damage done by Malaria was a key driver in delaying the Union's victory in the US Civil war, as well as the British defeat in the US revolutionary war, and Napoleon's defeat in the Caribbean that catalyzed the Louisiana Purchase. - Prior to the dawn of the "Galleon Trade", China was not interested in trade with the rest of the world, because it was by almost every objective measure of economy, technology, and public health, the greatest country on earth. Spain however discovered enormous silver mines in recently colonized Peru at the same time that China was going through a currency crisis whereby they needed silver. A huge center of trade erupted in the Philippines whereby the Spaniards mined silver with slaves in Peru, sailed it to Manila where they exchanged it for silk and other Chinese goods, and returned those goods back to Spain where they were STILL CHEAPER than European cotton and wool products after enormous markups.- The amount of silver mined in the Americas in the late 1500's, and the rampant spending of the Spanish crown at the same time, destabilized the country and spread across Europe. The cost of living doubled in 50 years+, ushering in sweeping unrest and revolution- The Little Ice Age, which killed millions of people across the planet, overturning entire dynasties, like the Ming in China- Tobacco trade between Virginia and Europe involved sailing boats from England to VA that carried barrels filled with dirt (as ballast). Those barrels were then emptied in Virginia and replaced with tobacco. Worms did not exist in North America prior to this moment, but arrived in that dirt. They totally transformed the North American environment. Tobacco farming also decimated huge areas, as Tobacco sucks all of the nitrogen out of soil, and is not replaced (because the whole plant is removed for harvest)- Tobacco farming in Virginia was creating enormous returns (+1000% in a few years) for investors, but labor was difficult to come by. Churches were employed, and ministers evangelized adventure to the new world or co-invest- The european honeybee was also brought to the Americas and exploded in population. European agriculture in the Americas almost surely would not have succeeded without it, despite pollonization not being discovered until the 1800s (Europeans wanted the honey).- Zheng He led a Chinese armada in the 1400s that had >300 ships (>2x the size of the famous Spanish Armada) and sailed all the way to Africa. China soon after abandoned naval trade. Mann points to Chinese bureaucracy shutting it down after a failed attempt to control it. In fact, China retained a naval tradition, only among independent pirate states. Mann's descriptions of the pirate-states in Fujian during the Ming dynasty sounds absolutely fascinating. I suspect there are incredible adventure stories about those days. - The story of Brazil'srubber boom in the Amazon rainforest was also fascinating, and life in Belem and Manaus at the time sounds incredible. Rubber was a necessary material for the industrial revolution. The expansion of rubber agriculture across South East Asia has totally transformed the ecosystem out there. It's only a matter of time before a blight destroys these rubber crops, which will have huge global impact.- For every European who came to the Americas, 3 Africans made the trip (mostly due to the slave trade). Since there were already 10's of millions of people already in the Americas when Europeans and Africans arrived, most of the human interactions occurred between Africans and Indians. But their interactions are the least told story of the New World- Throughout much of West Africa during the period of the Columbian Exchange, governments were organized such that the royal families owned all of the land. The most valuable assets in those societies, therefore, became labor. As a result, slavery within Africa quite common. 17th century West Africa was very politically fragmented, and war commonly broke out that resulted in mass enslavement of the loser. Almost all of the slave trade that resulted between Europeans and Africans was in fact slaves purchased in Africa from an existing market.Also fascinating was Manila during the Galleon Trade (late 16th through early 18th century). The city was racially serrated, and the Chinese were forced into maze-like neighborhoods outside of the city proper. The Chinese were there to trade with the nervous Spaniards, who on a dozen different occasions sacked and razed the Chinese neighborhoods whenever fears over the balance of economic or political power bent too far in China's favor. Tens of thousands of Chinese were killed during these events, yet soon after regular trade returned. Other interesting stuff:- One theory as to why the state of China was so much more developed than anything in the west is that it was a hydraulic empire, which needed to organize much earlier in order to control rivers that frequently flooded so as to manage agriculture.- There is far more variety of potatoes than what we can normally get in the US. More than 3,700 varieties are documented.- Japanese samurai roamed the roads of Mexico, and were employed to keep the peace there / protect Spanish silver shipments from the Galleon trade. Many had gone to the Philippenes in 1603-1609 for work, and were not allowed back in Japan when the country decided to close off its borders to outsiders in the 1630s.

An impartial, illuminating and entertaining voyage through history from the year after "Colòn" landed in Hispaniola to today. A necessary perspective and a fun ride.The obvious comparisons are Harari's "Sapiens", and "Guns, Germs, and Steel" by Diamond. Extra points to "1493" for timeliness. Mann has a light hand while digging deeeeep into the story of how we ended up here, now, with THIS system. We all know the main players, but maybe not as well as you might think. For one thing (call me ignorant) but I had no idea of how advanced were the Native civilizations in the New World. In many cases they had the upper hand over the Europeans, and not just because they knew the territory. They weren't just treading lightly through the vast forests, picking berries and shooting deer. The Natives had huge and intricate civilizations with agriculture and highly-developed social systems. On the other hand, the Europeans are usually cast as the big tough bad guys of the story, after all, they "won" and sadly the Native Americans were essentially exterminated, but here the Europeans get the "Fortune's Fools" treatment, bascially getting helplessly blown about the globe on a tempest of their own making. Mann gives you these perspectives without preaching. He serves you the story and you can draw your own conclusions.Still the meat of book isn't the potentially illuminating perspective on modern times, but the stories of history. Stuff like the endlessly fascinating history of "The Potato in the World", and the subsequent International Guano Crisis. Yeah, bird poop. For decades is was more valuable than gold, and for good reason within the economic system of the time. (Makes you wonder how "fossil fuels" will be laughed at centuries from now.) The story of how Spain began globalization in the early 1500's by meeting the Chinese on the shores of the Philippines while trading Mexican silver. The tragic and unusual history of slavery in the world. And if we think today's virus is bad (I do, of course), well, throughout history, almost up to present times, malaria and smallpox and yellow fever killed so many people, it makes your head spin. This review is really just skimming over the top of an excellent read. Highly recommended.

I really enjoyed this one. I love those history books that take me on a vast, all-encompassing journey across space and time to see a big picture more clearly than I ever had before.Of course, most people are aware of how Columbus changed the course of human history when he bumbled his way into the Americas. Much has been made of the great exchange of crops and animals that altered the course of history as well. What I think that most people don’t fully grasp is the epic scale of the Columbian Exchange. It is not just historic in the human sense, it is historic in the geologic and natural sense. Much has been made of the Anthropocene, the period during which human activity has been the dominant influence on climate and the environment, but few have recognized that Columbus’s accidental discovery was the key moment that set it off.I’m not sure if Columbus, as a navigator and flawed visionary, deserves much credit for the epic transformation he touched off any more than a moron who tossed aside a lit cigarette and sets off a massive wildfire deserves any particular credit. The tides of history would’ve pushed the two separate worlds together at some point not far off from 1992, even if that Italian stumblebum had never been born.And so we have a wonderful chronicle here of all the cultural, economic, and biological impacts that gone to make the modern world since contact all encapsulated in a series of historic moments across the planet. Globalization has almost become a natural force beyond human control, like a hurricane or an erupting volcano. What a frightening and epic journey for all of us little people being blown along in its winds. Even the election of a series of populist politicians across the world who have exploited people’s fear and ignorance in a futile attempt to turn back the clock is really a symptom of the unstoppable whirlwind set off by Columbus.I could go on and on about all that I learned and enjoyed here but, I think, you should just read the book and take the journey yourself.

Everyone should read this book and its predecessor, 1491. These books contain the true history of the world, written in an easy voice, making the truth easier to swallow for so many of us, I included, who were told an alternative version to the facts. Yes, it is an eye-opener. There are parts that will fascinate you, like the plight of the lowly potato, and parts that will disgust you, like realizing no one on the planet could possibly be immune to the tragedy of slavery. And, as the saying goes, 'It' doesn't affect you, until it Effects You. What fascinates me most, is how the truth is always revealed. Even if it is written in a book few will read, it's there for anyone to read. But the truth is sometimes scary, it could mean having your life changed in ways you never imagined. It could mean having no choice but to accept facts you've chosen to ignore. Or maybe you didn't know and your only excuse is now ignorance. Well, here's your chance to educate yourself to the truth.It took me a little over a year to read both these books, doing so for a few minutes each night before going to bed. I was able to pick these books up and read, remembering what I'd read the night or even the week before, as I continued on through passages of time I had not known existed. Wars, battles, kingdoms, colonies, and the lives of the people who lived and died in them kept me coming back to the end. Thank you, Charles C. Mann, for these carefully researched and written manuals. May they enlighten all who read them.

Like it's predecessor 1491, this bill challenges you to rethink your understanding of what you think you know about history. While 1491 focused on pre Columbus America, 1493 focuses on the many impacts that uniting the world through trade and discovery had. From the agricultural bounty of the Americas feeding and being responsible for population growth in Europe, to malaria and yellow fever decimating Native American and European alike, to silver flooding China and African maroon communities, globalization as we know it is has shaped our world for half a millennia. This book was absolutely fascinating in its breadth and detail, and how many things we assume to be culture- specific were really borrowed from elsewhere (e.g. tomatoes from America in Italian cooking). In a time when oceans of ink are split on the benefits and ills of globalization and whether it should continue (as if we could stop it), it's extremely interesting to learn the impacts that already happened and how they shape the world we know. Anyone and everyone should read this book. You'll learn something, you'll have to think, you'll be amazed at how integrated the world truly is.

What a fascinating book! Mann untangles many of the ecological and human consequences of the meeting of worlds and mixing of species and cultures that started with the establishment of an ongoing European presence in the Americas. For example -- Europeans overturned many Native American cultural practices in ways that made perfect breeding grounds for disease-carrying mosquitoes that were recently introduced from Africa. Africans were far more resistant to both malaria and yellow fever than were either Europeans or North Americans. This may have been one of the economic forces that caused the American south to be founded primarily on African chattel slavery rather than European indentured servitude. We see the potato go from America to Ireland and create a population boom, followed by the tragedy of the famine when the potato blight follows after. There are so many amazing stories here -- biology, warfare, economics, suffering, resistance. Highly recommended.

Mann’s account is a powerful reminder that the commodities and products we enjoy today were furnished for us at a terrible cost. Europeans and natives alike, producing sugar and rum for export from the Caribbean, succumbed to epidemics of yellow fever. The demand for more and more rubber led to wars in the Amazon and to forest depletion and water depletion in Laos today. And mining fertilizer in the form of guano resulted in the most atrocious forms of slavery in Peru. Mann does not spare the painful details as to the damage wrought on individual people and on their societies. Yet sometimes it’s hard to evaluate the benefits against the harms. Transplanting the potato to Europe and the sweet potato to China created “catastrophic social and environmental problems,” Mann shows, yet he argues that these vegetables may well have prevented malnutrition. These are stories in which the law of unexpected consequences rules and we will certainly for centuries be living with those consequences.
